questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency?
questions.solution:
11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency is associated with metabolic alkalosis, not metabolic acidosis.

It is a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia that presents with the following features:

  • Glucocorticoid deficiency:
    • Hypoglycemia
    • Hyperpigmentation around the genitals due to excess adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) secretion 
  • Mineralocorticoid excess:
    • Hypokalemia
    • Hypertension
    • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Adrenal androgen excess
    • Virilization in females
    • Precocious puberty in males

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-hydroxylase deficiency 17-hydroxylase deficiency 11β-hydroxylase deficiency 3β-HSD deficiency

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone

Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones

Deficiency of cortisol

Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone, and testosterone

↑ in testosterone

 ↑ in aldosterone ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone  ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for patients with type 2 brittle asthma is:
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for type II brittle asthma is subcutaneous adrenaline.

Brittle asthma is a type of severe asthma where patients have very serious and often, life-threatening attacks despite appropriate therapy. It is of two types:

Type 1 Type 2

A persistent pattern of variability in PEFR (peak expiratory flow rate) readings

Generally normal or near-normal PEFR readings but few unpredictable exacerbations occur without an obvious trigger
Oral steroids, infusion of bronchodilators, and dietary exclusion of allergens may be helpful  Respond only to subcutaneous epinephrine

questions.text: A pathologist is studying the following FNAC from a patient's thyroid nodule. Which is the most common site of metastasis for this condition?
questions.solution:
The FNAC image is suggestive of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Among the given options, the most common site of metastasis is the lungs.

The histological features of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid are:

  • Papillary architecture
  • Nuclear findings (enough to diagnose the condition even in the absence of papillary architecture)
    • Nuclear overlapping, grooving, crowding
    • Ground-glass appearance (Orphan Annie eye nuclei)
    • Dusty and pale chromatin
    • Intranuclear inclusion bodies

The most common mode of spread overall is through the lymphatic route, with lymph node metastases being common at initial presentation. 

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: A 61-year-old with CML failed to respond to imatinib therapy. Further evaluation revealed a T315I mutation. What drug should he be started on?
questions.solution:
Ponatinib is effective in patients with CML with T315I mutations. It is a third-generation tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

The T315I mutation in BCR-ABL clones is specifically resistant to therapy with imatinib, dasatinib, nilotinib, and bosutinib but is sensitive to the third-generation agent ponatinib. It is also used in the treatment of accelerated and blast phases.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about gastrointestinal stromal tumour?

choices.text: Originates from interstitial cells of cajal
Most common mesenchymal tumour of GIT
ALK gene mutatition is seen in most of the cases

questions.solution:
ALK gene mutation is not seen in most of cases of GIST.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors(GIST) are the most common sarcomatous tumors of the GI tract. They are derived from the interstitial cells of Cajal, intestinal pacemaker cell.

They are usually found in the stomach(40 - 60%), small intestine(30%) and colon(15%).

Overexpression of c-kit protooncogene is seen in 95% of these tumors and CD34+ in 60 - 70% of tumors.

The malignant potential of these tumors are assessed based on tumor size and mitotic activity.

The mainstay of treatment id complete surgical resection. Depending on tumor size, resection can include wide local excision, enucleation, sleeve gastrectomy, or total gastrectomy, with or without en bloc resection of adjacent organs.

questions.text: Causes of acute pancreatitis are all except______
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia causes acute pancreatitis but acute pancreatitis leads to Hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man who presented with progressive weakness was found to have a mix of upper and lower motor neuron findings on examination. His father and his cousin had passed away in their 40s due to similar symptoms. A mutation of the gene encoding which of the following enzymes is likely implicated here?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. This condition is linked to mutations of the gene encoding copper-zinc (Cu, Zn) superoxide dismutase type 1 (SOD1). Familial ALS accounts for about 10% of all ALS cases.

 

Option B: Mutations in the NADPH oxidase genes cause chronic granulomatous disease (CGD).

Option C: Hereditary deficiency of myeloperoxidase (MPO) predisposes to immune deficiency.

Option D: Glutathione peroxidase deficiency leads to hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis predominantly based on?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of ALS is based on clinical criteria that include the presence of upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron signs, the progression of the disease, and the absence of an alternative explanation. 

 

There is no single diagnostic test that can confirm or entirely exclude the diagnosis of motor neuron disease in general and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) in particular.

The revised El Escorial criteria and, more recently, the newer Awaji criteria are being used for the diagnosis of ALS.

Practically, the diagnosis is made when it is suggested by the history and physical examination, supported by electrodiagnostic studies (EMG & NCS), and not excluded by neuroimaging (MRI) and laboratory studies (CSF, blood, and urine analysis). Increased signal in the corticospinal tracts on T2-weighted MRI, if seen, is supportive of the diagnosis of ALS 

Muscle biopsy is not a routine part of the diagnostic evaluation of ALS but should be performed if there is clinical suspicion of inflammatory myopathy.

Genetic testing is not a routine part of the diagnostic evaluation in ALS except in cases where familial ALS (10%) is suspected.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT used in prevention of acute exacerbation of bronchiectasis?

choices.text: Administration of an oral antibiotic (e.g., ciprofloxacin) daily for 1–2 weeks per month
Long term macrolide therapy in Nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) associated bronchiectasis
Inhalation of aerosolized antibiotics on a rotation schedule
Intermittent administration of IV antibiotics for patients with more severe bronchiectasis

questions.solution:
Long-term macrolide therapy is not used to prevent acute exacerbations in nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) associated bronchiectasis due to development of macrolide resistance. 

In patients with recurrences of exacerbations (e.g., ≥3 episodes per year), following suppressive treatments may be employed to prevent further exacerbations:

  • Administration of an oral antibiotic (e.g., ciprofloxacin) daily for 1–2 weeks per month
  • Use of a rotating schedule of oral antibiotics (to minimize the risk of development of drug resistance)
  • Administration of a macrolide antibiotic daily or three times per week
  • Inhalation of aerosolized antibiotics (e.g., tobramycin inhalation solution) on a rotating schedule (e.g., 30 days on, 30 days off) and
  • Intermittent administration of IV antibiotics (e.g., “clean-outs”) for patients with more severe bronchiectasis and/or resistant pathogens.

questions.text: Which of the following is an epithelial tumor of the stomach?
questions.solution:
Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor of the stomach.

Adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy (90% cases) of the stomach.

Option A: Carcinoid tumor is a neuroendocrine tumor.

Option B: Lymphoma is a lymphoid tumor.

Option C: GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding adiponectin?

choices.text: Its levels are increased in obesity

questions.solution:
Adiponectin levels are reduced in obesity.

It is an abundant adipose-derived protein with the following characteristics: 

  • Its levels are reduced in obesity
  • It enhances insulin sensitivity and lipid oxidation
  • Has vascular-protective effects

On the other hand, resistin and RBP4 levels, which are also secreted by adipocytes, may induce insulin resistance.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl has had a history of recurrent bulky stools and abdominal pain since 3 years of age. She has pallor, and her weight and height are below the 3rd percentile. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation to make a specific diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A small intestinal biopsy can help diagnose documented steatorrhea or chronic diarrhea (>3 weeks). Failure to thrive in the setting of recurrent bulky stools and abdominal pain suggests a diagnosis of chronic malabsorption.

Endoscopy is the preferred method of obtaining histologic material from the proximal small-intestinal mucosa.

The other options are not specific tests used to confirm malabsorption syndromes.

Lesions seen on small-bowel biopsy can be classified into three categories according to their distribution and specificity of findings; diseases in which these lessons are seen and the associated pathologic findings are given below:

Patchy, Specific

Diffuse, Nonspecific

Folate deficiency Short villi, decreased mitosis in crypts, megalocytosis

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman has hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and decreased urinary phosphate excretion. The injection​ of parathyroid hormone (PTH) causes an increase in urinary cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is hypoparathyroidism after thyroid surgery.

Low blood Ca2+ and high blood phosphate are consistent with hypoparathyroidism.

Lack of parathyroid hormone (PTH) decreases bone resorption, decreases renal reabsorption of Ca2+, and increases renal reabsorption of phosphate (causing low urinary phosphate).

Because the patient responded to exogenous PTH with an increase in urinary cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP), the G protein coupling the PTH receptor to adenylate cyclase is apparently normal. Consequently, pseudohypoparathyroidism is excluded.

Vitamin D intoxication would cause hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia, while Vitamin D deficiency would cause hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia.

Hypoparathyroidism: It is most commonly a result of thyroid surgery, or it is congenital.

It is characterized by the following:

  • Decreased serum Ca2+ (hypocalcemia) and tetany
  • Increased serum phosphate (hyperphosphatemia)
  • Decreased urinary phosphate excretion

questions.text: You can advise any of the following tests for screening of a patient suspected to be having Cushing's syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Determination of plasma ACTH levels is not advised as a screening test for a patient with Cushing's syndrome.

Plasma ACTH determination is done to distinguish between ACTH-dependent and independent causes. It is done after the screening or confirmation of Cushing's syndrome.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: What are the most common cells involved in non-functioning pituitary adenoma?
questions.solution:
Non-functioning pituitary adenomas most commonly arise from gonadotropic cells (80%). 

Pituitary adenomas are classified as functioning or non-functioning based on the secretion of hormones. Non-functioning adenomas are usually asymptomatic in the initial stages but as the tumor grows larger, mass effect produces clinical manifestations such as:

  • Headache
  • Bitemporal hemianopia 
  • Diplopia, ptosis 
  • Compression of pituitary stalk
    • Hyperprolactinemia initially - reduced dopamine release leads to loss of inhibition of lactotrophs
    • Hypopituitarism in later stages

Related Pearl: Cells of Anterior Pituitary

questions.text: Pseudoachalasia can be seen in all the following conditions except ______
questions.solution:
Pseudoachalasia is not seen in Diffuse esophageal spasm

Pseudoachalasia is a condition that mimics Achalasia and can be seen with :

  • Carcinoma in the gastric fundus 
  • Carcinoma in distal esophagus
  • Paraneoplastic syndrome with circulating antineuronal antibodies (rare)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most frequently observed cutaneous manifestation of MEN1 syndrome?
questions.solution:
The most frequently observed cutaneous manifestation of MEN1 syndrome is angiofibroma.

Cutaneous tumors in MEN1 Syndrome are:

  • Angiofibroma – 85%
  • Collagenoma – 70%
  • Lipoma - 33%

questions.text: Low serum copper levels attributed to ATP7A gene is due to:
questions.solution:
Low serum copper level attributed to the ATP7A gene is due to Menke's disease (Option C).

Menke's disease or Menke-Kinky hair syndrome is an X-linked recessive condition occurring due to a mutation in the ATP7A gene on chromosome X. This causes impaired transport of dietary copper from the small intestine to the liver leading to low levels of copper-containing enzymes. It presents within 3 years of age and is characterized by:

  • Depigmented kinky hair
  • Failure to thrive
  • Neurodegenerative symptoms like loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, epilepsyLoose, wrinkled skin
  • Multiple fractures
  • Poor visual acuity
  • Recurrent infections.

Lab investigations show low serum copper (<65 μg/dL) and low ceruloplasmin(<20 mg/dl). The disease is fatal as it has no curative treatment. But, administration of L-histidine and copper chloride injections may be beneficial, if started early.

Aceruloplasminemia is an autosomal recessive disease characterized by tissue iron overload, mental deterioration, microcytic anemia, and low serum iron and copper concentrations.

Option B: Low serum copper and low ceruloplasmin is also seen in Wilson’s disease, but is associated with the gene defect ATP7B on chromosome 13. It is an autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism with features of hepatolenticular degeneration and Kayser Fleischer ring.   

Option A: Dubin Johnson Syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired canalicular excretion of bilirubin due to mutation in MRP-2 protein leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 

Option D: Gilbert’s Syndrome is characterized by decreased UDP glucuronyl transferase activity leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which can be autosomal recessive or dominant.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of acute myeloid leukemia?
questions.solution:
The most common type of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is AML - M2 or AML with maturation.

The least common type of AML is AML M7 or megakaryocytic.

questions.text: A flow-volume loop of a patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is tracheal stenosis. The flow-volume loop shows flattened inspiratory and expiratory curves, suggestive of fixed upper-airway obstruction.

A normal flow-volume loop begins on the X-axis (Volume axis): at the start of the test, both flow and volume are equal to zero. After the starting point, the curve rapidly mounts to a peak: Peak expiratory flow (PEF).

Then, the PEF the curve descends (=the flow decreases) as more air is expired. A normal, non-pathological F/V loop will descend in a straight or a convex line from the top (PEF) to the bottom (FVC).

The forced inspiration that follows the forced expiration has roughly the same morphology, but the PIF (Peak Inspiratory Flow) is not as distinct as PEF.

questions.text: Which of the following would you not see in a patient with pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia is seen in patients with pheochromocytoma, not hypocalcemia. This is due to the production of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) by the tumor. 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Classical triad of symptoms:
    • Headaches – most common symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension (sustained or intermittent) – most common sign
  • Anxiety, panic attacks
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Pallor - due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction
  • Polyuria and polydipsia 
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis, high hematocrit (hemoconcentration)
  • Constipation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss
  • Nausea

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as diagnostic criteria of an exudative pleural effusion?

choices.text: Pleural fluid LDH more than 2/3rds upper limit of normal for serum

questions.solution:
Cell count > 500 is not used as a diagnostic criteria of an exudative pleural effusion.

Light’s criteria is used to distinguish between exudative and transudative pleural effusions.

An exudative pleural effusion satisfies at least one of the following criteria.

  • Pleural fluid protein / serum protein > 0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH / serum LDH > 0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH more than 2/3rds upper limit of normal for serum

questions.text: A patient with a suspected pulmonary embolism underwent a chest X-ray. It showed an enlarged right descending pulmonary artery.  What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
Enlarged right descending pulmonary artery on a chest X-ray in pulmonary embolism is called Palla’s sign.

The black pleura sign is seen in alveolar pulmonary microlithiasis. It refers to the shadow of the pleura between the extensive alveolar calcification and the adjacent rib cage.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman presents with cough and shortness of breath. The physician conducts a pulmonary function screening test in his office, and the patient generates the maximum expiratory flow–volume curve shown to the right of the normal curve in the diagram below. These findings are consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This is a case of asbestosis.

Asbestosis is a restrictive lung disease characterized by diffuse interstitial fibrosis. In restrictive lung disease, the maximum expiratory flow volume (MEFV) curve begins and ends at abnormally low lung volumes.

Note: In obstructive lung diseases, the airways are narrowed or radial traction of the airways is reduced, allowing them to close more easily. The lung volumes in these cases are higher than normal.

questions.text: What is the most common myeloproliferative neoplasm?
questions.solution:
The most common myeloproliferative neoplasm is polycythemia vera. 

It is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder that is characterized by uncontrolled proliferation of the red blood cells in the body. It is also frequently associated with an increase in white blood cells and platelets.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in patients with brain stem injury?
questions.solution:
Patients with brain stem injury develop type 2 respiratory failure. It is characterized by low pO2 and high pCO2.

Acute respiratory failure refers to acute impairment in gas exchange between the lungs and the blood causing hypoxia with or without hypercapnia.

questions.solution:

questions.solution:
Serum amylase levels are not included in Ranson’s criteria.

Ranson's prognostic criteria after 48 hours of admission
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis 
Hematocrit fall

Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL <8 mg/dL
Base deficit >4 mEq/L >5 mEq/L

≥5 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration

  >6 L  >4 L

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

Score Interpretation

  • 0 to 2 points: 0% to 3% mortality
  • 3 to 4 points: 15% mortality
  • 5 to 6 points: 40% mortality
  • 7 to 11: nearly 100% mortality

questions.text: What is the most common symptom of thyrotoxicosis?
questions.solution:
Hyperactivity and irritability are considered as the most common symptoms of thyrotoxicosis.

The following table summarizes the symptoms and signs of thyrotoxicosis in descending order of frequency:

Symptoms Signs
  • Hyperactivity, irritability, dysphoria
  • Heat intolerance and sweating
  • Palpitations
  • Fatigue and weakness
  • Weight loss with increased appetite
  • Diarrhoea
  • Polyuria
  • Oligomenorrhea, loss of libido
  • Tachycardia, atrial fibrillation in the elderly
  • Tremor
  • Goitre
  • Warm, moist skin
  • Muscle weakness, proximal myopathy
  • Lid retraction or lag
  • Gynecomastia

Rarely, there can be an associated mid-systolic heart murmur called the Means-Lerman scratch. This is heard in the upper part of the sternum caused by the rubbing of the pericardium and the pleura, due to the hyperdynamic circulation.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presented with chronic hematuria and dysuria. Microscopic examination of urine showed the following parasitic eggs. What type of bladder carcinoma is commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows oval-shaped eggs with the terminal spine which is characteristic of Schistosoma haematobium. It is most commonly associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.

The ova are deposited in the bladder wall and incite a brisk chronic inflammatory response. This induces progressive mucosal squamous metaplasia and dysplasia and, in some instances, neoplasia.

Schistosomal infection can less frequently result in adenocarcinoma or transitional cell carcinoma.

questions.text: In patients with which of the following is dabigatran approved for use?

choices.text: Metallic heart valve requiring stroke prophylaxis
Non-valvular atrial fibrillation requiring stroke prophylaxis

questions.solution:
Stroke prophylaxis in non-valvular atrial fibrillation is the only indication for which all DOACs are approved. All DOACs are contraindicated in patients with metallic/prosthetic heart valves.

Novel oral anticoagulants:

Thrombin inhibitors  Factor Xa inhibitors

  • Argatroban
  • Lepirudin
  • Desirudin
  • Bivalirudin
  • Rivaroxaban
  • Apixaban
  • Edoxaban
  • Betrixaban

Dabigatran is a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC). DOACs are alternatives to warfarin, easier to administer with fixed doses, and no requirement for monitoring.

Only rivaroxaban and apixaban are licensed for use as thromboprophylaxis after elective hip or knee arthroplasty.

questions.text: A patient comes to the sleep clinic and the following pattern is seen on polysomnography. What type of breathing pattern is it?
questions.solution:
The breathing pattern shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes respiration. It is characterized by progressively deeper and sometimes faster breathing, followed by a gradual decrease that results in a temporary stop in breathing called apnea.

It is caused by an increased sensitivity of the respiratory center to arterial PCO2. There is an apneic phase, during which arterial PO2 falls and arterial PCO2 rises. These changes in the arterial blood gas content stimulate the respiratory center, resulting in hyperventilation and hypocapnia, followed by recurrence of apnea. It is present in 40% of patients with advanced HF and usually is associated with low cardiac output.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a chronic history of smoking is diagnosed with small cell lung carcinoma. Which of the following statement is false regarding the management of the patient?

choices.text: In wedge resection, anatomical bronchopulmonary segment is removed.
Posterolateral thoracotomy approach is used for surgical resection.
Lobectomy is the treatment of choice for early-stage lung cancer.

questions.solution:
Wedge resection involves the non-anatomical excision of the tumor. Excision of the anatomical bronchopulmonary segment is called segmentectomy.

Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is a type of tumor that originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (Kulchitsky cells) in the lining bronchial epithelium. They tend to metastasize early to lymph nodes and by the blood-borne spread. 

SCLC is very responsive to chemotherapy such that median survival may be doubled.

Surgery for lung cancers:

Surgery with curative intent is offered to patients with early-stage lung cancer (T1–3, N0–1). Lung cancer resection can be approached through:

  • Posterolateral thoracotomy
  • Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS)

Complications of surgery include:

  • Bleeding
  • Respiratory infection
  • Persistent air-leak
  • Bronchopleural fistula

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with mild ptosis and proximal lower limb weakness. Nerve conduction studies show incremental response following brief exercise. Further investigations reveal antibodies against presynaptic P/Q voltage-gated calcium channels. Which of the following malignancies is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). It is associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.

It is an autoimmune disorder caused by antibodies that block acetylcholine release by inhibiting a presynaptic calcium channel. In contrast to myasthenia gravis, rapid, repetitive stimulation (muscle activity) results in an increase in muscle response and strength.

Patients typically present with weakness of their extremities. In about half the cases, there is an underlying malignancy; most often, neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung (Small cell lung carcinoma). The stimulus for autoantibody formation in paraneoplastic cases may be the expression of the same calcium channel in the neoplastic cells.

Patients without cancer often have other autoimmune diseases, such as vitiligo or thyroid disease. Treatment consists of drugs that increase acetylcholine release by depolarizing synaptic membranes (pyridostigmine), plasmapheresis, and immunosuppressive agents, similar to myasthenia gravis.

questions.text:
A patient with a testicular tumor is also found to have parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, and gastrinoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?

MEN: multiple endocrine neoplasia
questions.solution:
The most appropriate diagnosis, in this case, is MEN 4. 

Tumors associated with MEN 1 are parathyroid adenomas, pituitary adenomas, and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (PNETs) such as gastrinoma and insulinoma. When they occur in association with gonadal, adrenal, renal, and thyroid tumors, the patient is designated to have MEN 4 syndrome. 

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma

  • Adrenal cortical tumors

  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man presented with a 2-month history of fatigue, fever, and night sweats. On examination, generalized painless lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly were noted. Investigations revealed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?

Haemoglobin - 10g/dl

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with breathlessness on exertion and dry cough for 4 weeks. She has swollen joints and early morning stiffness for which she is on treatment for a few years. On auscultation, inspiratory fine crackles were heard. An HRCT was ordered and it showed bilateral, subpleural and basilar honeycombing pattern. PFT of the patient is likely to show which of the following patterns?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the HRCT findings are suggestive of interstitial lung disease (ILD). FEV1/FVC ratio >0.7 and decreased DLCO are likely to be seen in the PFT. A history of swollen joints and early morning stiffness hints at rheumatoid arthritis. It is associated with the usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern of ILD.

In ILD, restrictive pattern is seen on pulmonary function test, which is characterized by:

  • Decreased total lung capacity (TLC)
  • Decreased forced vital capacity (FVC)
  • Decreased residual volumes (RV)
  • Decreased DLCO (diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide)
  • FEV1/FVC ratio - normal or increased, >0.7

questions.text: A fisherman was rushed to the ED following a near-drowning incident. On arrival, he was unconscious and was not breathing. He was resuscitated and stabilized. A few hours later, he developed sudden onset breathlessness and low saturation. Chest X-ray showed diffuse alveolar opacities. He was started on mechanical ventilation. What will be the recommended ventilator setting for him?

choices.text: Low tidal volume and high PEEP
Low tidal volume and low PEEP
High tidal volume and high PEEP
High tidal volume and low PEEP

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ARDS secondary to drowning. The ventilator setting recommended is low tidal volume and high PEEP.

Drowning causes direct lung injury. The aspiration of water into the lungs damages the surfactant. This disrupts the alveolar-capillary membrane and leads to alveolar edema, resulting in ARDS.

The ventilator settings recommended in ARDS are:

  • Low tidal volume: To avoid barotrauma due to overdistention of the alveoli.
  • High PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure): This prevents the collapse of alveoli at the end of the expiration and improves oxygenation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about immune dysregulation polyendocrinopathy enteropathy X-linked (IPEX) syndrome?
questions.solution:
IPEX (immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, and X-linked) syndrome is caused by mutations in the FOXP3 gene, which leads to a deficiency of T-regulatory cells, resulting in immune dysfunction.

IPEX is associated with: 

  • Ulcerative colitis-like autoimmune enteropathy 
  • Neonatal type 1 DM
  • Thyroiditis
  • Dermatitis

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in the management of patients with tumor lysis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Sodium bicarbonate is not recommended in the treatment of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS).

Urinary alkalinization by sodium bicarbonate decreases the solubility of xanthine, hypoxanthine, and calcium phosphate. This potentially increases the risk of intratubular crystallization.

Management of TLS includes:

  • Aggressive hydration
  • Allopurinol
  • Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase
  • Febuxostat - non-purine selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presented with a history of diarrhea for 5 months, occasional abdominal pain, and weight loss. Upper GI endoscopy showed the following finding. Which of the following is least likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario and endoscopy image showing large, rugal gastric folds are suggestive of Menetrier's disease. Among the given options, hematemesis is least likely to occur in this patient.

Large, gastric rugal folds in Menetrier's disease occur due to massive overgrowth of mucous cells (foveolar cells) lining the stomach.

Patients usually present with epigastric pain, nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, anorexia, peripheral edema, and weight loss. Occult gastrointestinal bleeding may occur, but overt bleeding is unusual. If overt bleeding is seen, it is usually due to superficial mucosal erosions.

They develop protein-losing gastropathy, leading to hypoproteinemia as a result of increased secretion of gastric mucus. There is also a decrease in the number of parietal cells which leads to decreased acid secretion (hypochlorhydria) in the stomach. They are at an increased risk of developing gastric carcinoma.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty after he was hit by a plastic pipe on the back by a bully. On examination, the patient was found to have marked upper extremity weakness compared to the lower extremities. He also had a loss of pain and temperature sensations over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk. Other sensations were intact in this region. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of cape distribution of sensory deficit is seen in central cord syndrome. 

This condition affects the cervical cord producing arm weakness > leg weakness. A dissociated sensory loss i.e. loss of pain and temperature with preservation of light touch, joint position, and vibration sensations is seen over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk (cape distribution).

It results from selective damage to the gray matter nerve cells and the decussating spinothalamic tracts surrounding the central canal. These decussating fibers carry crude touch, pain, and temperature sensations.

Spinal trauma, syringomyelia, and intrinsic cord tumors are the main causes.

Option A: In Brown–Sequard Syndrome, ipsilateral weakness and loss of joint position and vibratory sense, with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense, one or two levels below the lesion is seen.

Option C: Anterior spinal artery syndrome is caused due to an ASA infarct. It typically presents as loss of motor function and pain/temperature sensation, with relative sparing of proprioception and vibratory sense below the level of the lesion.

Option D: In foramen magnum syndrome, compressive lesions near the foramen magnum may produce weakness of the ipsilateral shoulder and arm followed by weakness of the ipsilateral leg, then the contralateral leg, and finally the contralateral arm. This is referred to as 'around the clock' pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen as an extrahepatic manifestation in patients with hepatitis C infection?
questions.solution:
Polyarteritis nodosa is not characteristically associated with hepatitis C infection. However, it is a common extrahepatic manifestation of hepatitis B viral infection.

questions.text: What is the most common type of lung cancer in light smokers?
questions.solution:
The most common lung cancer in light smokers (<10 pack-year history) is adenocarcinoma. 

WHO classification of lung carcinomas:

The WHO classification system divides epithelial lung cancers into four major cell types:

  • Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC)
  • Non-small-cell lung carcinomas (NSCLCs)
    • Adenocarcinoma
    • Squamous cell carcinoma
    • Large-cell carcinoma

Adenocarcinoma is most commonly seen in:

  • Lifetime non-smokers
  • Light smokers (<10 pack-years history)
  • Women
  • Younger adults (<60 years)

In smokers, the most common types are small-cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinomas.

Related Pearl: Incidence of lung cancer according to histology

questions.text: Pituitary adenoma with mucocutaneous myxomas and pigmentary nevi are features of  ____________
questions.solution:
Pituitary adenoma with mucocutaneous myxomas and pigmentary nevi are features of Carney complex.

Carney complex (CNC) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by:

  • Skin lesions are the most common Carney complex manifestation. Spotty skin pigmentation (usually of the face, labia, and conjunctiva)
  • Myxomas (usually of the eyelids and heart, but also the tongue, palate, breast, and skin),
  • Psammomatous melanotic schwannomas (usually of the sympathetic nerve chain and upper gastrointestinal tract)
  • Endocrine tumors that involve the adrenals, Sertoli cells, somatotropes, thyroid, and ovary.
  • Null mutations in PRKAR1A, encoding a regulatory subunit of a cyclic-AMP-dependent protein kinase which results in Carney complex.
  • The most common type of endocrine tumors in Carney complex is the primary pigmented nodular adrenocortical disease (PPNAD) (present in two-thirds of the patients), a form of bilateral adrenal hyperplasia that leads to adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)-independent Cushing syndrome.
  • NAME syndrome and LAMB syndrome are synonymous with Carney complex. 
    • LAMB - Lentigines, Atrial myxoma, and Blue nevi. 
    • NAME - Nevi, Atrial myxoma, Myxoid neurofibromas, and Ephelides.

Loeys-Dietz syndrome is a connective tissue disorder which is similar to Marfan's syndrome and most commonly presents with aortic aneurysms, bifid uvula(cleft palate) and hypertelorism. It is caused by mutations in the genes that encode TGF-β receptors 1 & 2. 

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus is found to have a 24-hour urinary albumin of 250 mg. Which of the following drugs may be prescribed to reduce the progression of this condition?
questions.solution:
Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACEI) inhibitors or angiotensin-receptor blockers (ARB) are recommended to reduce the progression of diabetic nephropathy. It has the following effects:

  • Reduction of albuminuria
  • Reduces the associated decline in GFR 

The mainstay of management of diabetic nephropathy includes control of blood sugar and blood pressure, inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone(RAAS) system, and inhibitors of SGLT2 to halt the progression of the disease. 

RAAS inhibitors include ACE inhibitors, ARBs, or direct renin inhibitors.

Recently, the FDA approved finerenone, a nonsteroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist, to reduce the risk of sustained eGFR decline, end-stage renal disease, cardiovascular death, non-fatal heart attacks, and hospitalization for heart failure in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) associated with type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: A 25-year-old diabetic woman presents to the OPD with the following skin lesions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing irregular plaques with yellowish discoloration and telangiectasias are suggestive of necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum.

It is an inflammatory granulomatous disorder of the skin due to collagen degeneration and lipid deposition. It is usually seen in young women with diabetes mellitus.

The lesions usually begin in the pretibial region. It begins as papules that gradually enlarge and darken to form erythematous plaques with irregular margins, atrophic centers, and central ulceration.

Option A: Necrolytic migratory erythema is a feature of glucagonoma. It is a waxing and waning rash that appears as shown below.

Option B: Diabetic dermopathy or shin spots are commonly seen in elderly men. It presents as pigmented pretibial papules as shown below.

Option D: Granuloma annulare presents with small papules arranged in an annular pattern. There is no yellowish discoloration or telangiectasias, as shown below.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient with breathlessness, and dry cough on and off for the past 6 months. She provides a history of working in the sand filtration segment in a brick production unit for the last 15 years. An X-ray was done and is given below. Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis for the X-ray finding?
questions.solution:
The x-ray image shows eggshell calcification, Asbestosis is not a differential diagnosis for eggshell calcification.

There are no pathognomonic radiological features specific to asbestosis. Chest radiographs may show irregular opacities with a fine reticular pattern. Additional evidence of asbestos exposure such as calcified or noncalcified pleural plaques may be evident.

Related Pearl: Eggshell calcification of lymph node on chest X-ray

Eggshell calcification refers to fine calcification seen at the periphery of a lymph node. Causes are -

  • Silicosis (most common)
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Post radiotherapy
  • Post-irradiation lymphoma
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Blastomycosis
  • Amyloidosis
  • Tuberculosis

questions.text: A patient in the ICU is diagnosed with community acquired-MRSA. What is the best line of management?
questions.solution:
The Empiric treatment of choice for ICU in patients with suspected CA-MRSA is:

  • β-lactam (e.g., ceftriaxone) + Fluoroquinolone/Azithromycin

                   PLUS

  • Linezolid / Vancomycin with or without Clindamycin to cover CA-MRSA

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for an increased incidence of cancer in old age?
questions.solution:
Increased incidence of cancer in old age is due to telomerase reactivation.

Normally, with every cell division, there is some shortening of telomeres at the ends of chromosomes. Once the telomeres are shortened beyond a certain point, it may cause cell-cycle arrest or apoptosis. This is called replicative senescence.

Telomerase is the enzyme that prevents the shortening of telomeres. This enzyme is usually present in germ cells but is absent in most somatic cells.

Abnormal reactivation of telomerase in somatic cells leads to evasion of senescence and apoptosis. It enables the cells to divide several times than normal.

questions.text: A woman presents with recurrent episodes of blurry vision, tingling and numbness in the legs, and falls. She says that during hot weather, she finds it difficult to walk and often falls. Recently she had flu, due to which the symptoms aggravated. MRI brain was done which showed Dawson's fingers. What is the criteria used for the clinical diagnosis of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the MRI finding of Dawson's fingers are suggestive of multiple sclerosis. Revised McDonald’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. It takes into consideration the clinical attacks and objective lesions. In addition, it also involves the assessment of the lesions based on MRI and other imaging techniques.

The Kurtzke expanded disability status scale (EDSS) and functional status (FS) score are widely used measures of neurologic impairment, which are performed following the confirmed diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.

Related Pearl: The 2017 Revised McDonald Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple Sclerosis

questions.text: Atlanta classification is used for assessing severity of ____________
questions.solution:
Atlanta classification is used for assessing severity of acute pancreatitis .

Atlanta classification

Mild Acute Pancreatitis

  • No organ failure
  • No local or systemic complications

Moderately Severe Acute Pancreatitis

  • Transient organ failure (<48 hours) and/or
  • Local or systemic complications without persistent organ failure

Severe Acute Pancreatitis

  • Persistent organ failure (>48 hours)–single organ or multiorgan

Related Pearl: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

  • Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes:
    • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL
    • Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15
    • Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
    • Age > 60 years
    • Pleural effusion
      One point is given for each. BISAP score ≥ 3 indicates severe pancreatitis.
  • Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS)
    If all the following are present then it is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need for ventilation:
    • Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding
    • Normal hematocrit
    • Normal serum creatinine

  • Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II)
    • A score of 8 or more is considered to be severe
    • Can be done at admission and repeated any time
    • Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age
  • Ranson’s score
  • Modified Glasgow criteria - 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered to be severe
  • Atlanta classification

questions.text: A patient presented with loss of upgaze and convergence-retraction nystagmus. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of convergence-retraction nystagmus and loss of upgaze is seen in Parinaud's syndrome. It is caused by a lesion in the dorsal midbrain.

The following tetrad of symptoms are seen:

  1. Loss of upgaze
  2. Light-near dissociation
  3. Convergence-retraction nystagmus
  4. Lid retraction

Convergence‐retraction nystagmus is irregular, jerky nystagmus in which both eyeballs rhythmically converge and retract into the orbit, particularly on attempting an upward gaze.

Nothnagel syndrome is associated with oculomotor palsy and contralateral limb ataxia. Underlying structures involved are the superior cerebellar peduncle and tectum of the midbrain.

Related Pearl: Stroke syndromes with visual symptoms

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with an ischaemic stroke. His son says that he holds the comb incorrectly while combing his hair. During the evaluation, he was unable to button his shirt when requested. The lesion is most likely to be in which lobe?
questions.solution:
The given scenario where the patient is unable to perform learned skilled movements is suggestive of apraxia. The lesion is likely to be in the dominant parietal lobe as apraxia is a feature of a lesion in this area.

The features of dominant parietal lobe lesions are as follows:

  • Apraxia - inability to perform learned skilled movements
  • Acalculia - difficulty performing simple mathematical tasks
  • Alexia - inability to recognize or read written words or letters
  • Agnosia - inability to recognize and identify objects, persons, or sounds
  • Dysphasia - language disorder marked by deficiency in the generation of speech and its comprehension
  • Contralateral inferior homonymous quadrantanopia
  • Gerstmann syndrome (acalculia, dysgraphia, finger agnosia, right-left confusion)

Features of non-dominant parietal lobe lesions include:

  • Spatial disorientation
  • Constructional apraxia
  • Contralateral inferior homonymous quadrantanopia
  • Contralateral hemineglect.

questions.text: A 69-year-old business tycoon is diagnosed with multiple myeloma. He is worried about his business empire and asks you how long he will survive. Which of the following is the best predictor for this?
questions.solution:
Serum β2-microglobulin levels are the best modality to predict the median survival period. 

Albumin levels alone cannot be used to predict the median survival period. It is used in combination with β2-microglobulin for risk stratification.

Patients with β2-microglobulin levels <3.5 mg/L and albumin levels > 3.5 g/dl have a median survival period of 5 years. Those with levels >3.5 mg/L and albumin < 3.5 g/dl have a survival period of fewer than 2 years.

Durie-Salmon staging is unable to predict outcomes with newer agents. Hence it is no longer used.

Factors associated with poor prognosis: 

  • Plasma cell labeling index 
  • Chromosomal aberrations
  • Circulating plasma cells
  • Performance status
  • Highly elevated LDH
  • Extramedullary disease
  • De novo plasma cell leukemia

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy presented with steatorrhea and chronic diarrhea. An evaluation revealed delayed intellectual development and ataxia. Acanthocytes were seen on the peripheral blood smear. Ophthalmological examination showed the following. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image showing retinitis pigmentosa and presence of acanthocytes along with the given clinical features is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia.

Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare genetic disorder in which there is defective chylomicron formation. Chylomicrons are required for the absorption and transport of fats and fat-soluble vitamins.

It presents in early childhood with steatorrhoea and diarrhea, hypolipidemia, failure to thrive, ataxia, sensory and motor neuropathies.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man chronic smoker presented with flecks of blood in his sputum. He is currently on treatment for COPD and hypertension. His BMI is 31 kg/m² and he has central obesity. His RBS is 261 mg/dl. During further evaluation, he is found to have high ACTH levels that remained high even after administration of high-dose dexamethasone. What is the underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Elevated ACTH levels that do not get suppressed by a high-dose dexamethasone test are suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome secondary to an ectopic ACTH-secreting tumor. Considering the patient's smoking history and presentation with hemoptysis, it is likely to be a lung tumor.

Dynamic testing for Cushing’s syndrome
  High dose dexamethasone suppression test CRH stimulation test
Pituitary adenoma Positive (suppressed cortisol) Positive (increase in ACTH and cortisol)
Ectopic ACTH Negative Negative
Iatrogenic: Suppressed ACTH levels that are not affected by dynamic testing
Adrenal mass or hyperplasia:  Suppressed ACTH levels that are not affected by dynamic testing

Ectopic sources of ACTH include small cell lung cancers and pulmonary carcinoid tumors. The most effective treatment strategy is the management of the underlying SCLC or carcinoid.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic factors has been implicated in patients with alcoholic liver disease?
questions.solution:
Patatin-like phospholipase domain-containing protein 3 (PNPLA3) has been associated with alcoholic liver disease

Option B: PTEN is a tumor suppressor gene. Mutation of this gene is associated with Cowden syndrome that leads to multiple cancers like breast cancer, prostate cancer, endometrial cancer, and colorectal cancer.

Option C: HFE gene is associated with genetic hemochromatosis.

Option D: MRP2 protein is associated with Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

questions.text: The auto-antibody that is associated with myasthenia gravis, from the following, is _______

choices.text: Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LPR4) antibody

questions.solution:
One of the auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis is anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LPR4) antibodies

 

Related Pearl: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient with Crohn’s disease has had a disappointing response to glucocorticoids and 5-aminosalicyclic acid (5-ASA) agents. He is interested in steroid-sparing agents. He has no liver or renal disease. You prescribe once-weekly methotrexate injections. In addition to monitoring hepatic function and complete blood count, what other complication of methotrexate therapy do you advice the patient of?
questions.solution:
The patient must be advised regarding possible pneumonitis while on methotrexate therapy.

Methotrexate, azathioprine, cyclosporine, tacrolimus, and anti-tumour necrosis factor(TNF) antibody are reasonable options for patients with Crohn disease, depending on the extent of macroscopic disease. Pneumonitis is a rare but serious complication of methotrexate therapy.

Other options:

  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis is an extraintestinal manifestation of IBD and not a complication of methotrexate therapy.
  • Pancreatitis is an uncommon complication of azathioprine, and IBD patients treated with azathioprine are at four-fold increased risk of developing a lymphoma.
  • Anti-TNF antibody therapy is associated with an increased risk of tuberculosis, disseminated histoplasmosis, and a number of other infections.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with progressive fatigue and weight loss for 3 months. CBC showed pancytopenia. On peripheral smear, the following cells were seen, which also showed positive staining with TRAP. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows mononuclear cells with abundant pale blue-grey agranular cytoplasm with elongated (hairy) projections, which are TRAP-positive. This clinical scenario is suggestive of hairy cell leukemia. The drug of choice is cladribine.

Hairy cell leukemia is responsive to chemotherapy with interferon α, pentostatin, and cladribine. However, cladribine is the preferred drug of choice due to complete remission in the majority of patients, and higher rates of long-term disease-free survival. It is administered daily for 7 days by continuous intravenous infusion.

Chemotherapy-refractory patients have responded to vemurafenib, a BRAF inhibitor. Splenectomy is often associated with prolonged remission.

questions.text: In Guillain-Barre syndrome due to antecedent infection with Campylobacter jejuni, the autoantibodies are most commonly directed against which of the following?
questions.solution:
Autoantibodies in GBS due to Campylobacter jejuni infection are directed most commonly against GM1 gangliosidase.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in Guillian Barre syndrome

Type Antibody
AIDP Anti GM1
AMAN Anti GD1a
AMSAN Anti GD1a
Miller Fisher syndrome Anti GQ1b
  • AIDP-Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy 
  • AMAN-Acute motor axonal neuropathy 
  • AMSAN-Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy

questions.text: The bile acid pool size is?
questions.solution: The bile acid pool size is 4g.The pool is circulated via the enterohepatic circulation about twice during each meal, or six to eight times during a 24 hour period.

questions.text: In a patient with a left-sided massive pneumothorax, all of the following ECG changes are seen except:
questions.solution:
Right axis deviation is seen in left-sided pneumothorax. 

The ECG changes seen in left-sided pneumothorax are as follows:

  • Reduced R wave amplitude
  • Inversion of T wave in precordial leads
  • Amplitude changes in QRS complex
  • Right axis deviation

questions.text: Clinical criteria for brain death include all except:
questions.solution:
Clinical criteria for brain death does not include absent spinal cord reflexes. Deep tendon reflexes/spinal cord reflexes may be present in brain death as the spinal cord is intact.

Criteria for brain death:

  • Coma - Deep, unresponsiveness to noxious stimuli
  • Absence of brainstem reflexes - Pupillary, oculocephalic, corneal, gag reflex, etc.
  • Apnea - Absence of spontaneous respiration at arterial pCO2 tension of at least 50–60mm Hg

questions.text: Which of the following findings will you not expect to see in a patient with SIADH?

choices.text: Normal serum urea and creatinine levels

questions.solution:
SIADH does not cause hypernatremia. SIADH is the most common cause of euvolemic hyponatremia. 

The excess ADH secreted leads to the gain of water in the body. This stimulates baroreceptors to release atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP). ANP leads to the loss of water and salt in the urine, leading to urine sodium level of > 20 mEq/L in these patients. Thus, the level of water reaches a steady state (euvolemia) but the urinary loss of sodium continues to occur, giving rise to hyponatremia.

SIADH is characterized by low levels of uric acid, normal blood pressure, and normal urea and creatinine levels.

SIADH is diagnosed based on the following criteria (Bartter-Schwartz criteria):

1. Reduced serum osmolality
2. Urine osmolality > Serum osmolality
3. Clinical euvolemia
4. Increased levels of urinary sodium
5. Absence of other causes of hyponatremia like pituitary, renal, adrenal, thyroid or liver diseases.
